Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

In my opinion, yes, listening to an audiobook is just as good as reading the paper pages of a book because it is the same story. You get the same information, and you can still enjoy the story. I personally know a person who taught themselves how to read using that method. It worked very well for them. 

I can not however say that an audiobook is better than good old fashion reading though because both do have minor differences about them like the fact that you can't see the words as you listen to the audiobook, or that you can't do other things while reading a book.

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, yes, listening to an audiobook is just as good as reading the paper pages of a book because it is the same story. You get the same information, and you can still enjoy the story. You still have to be involved with the story of course, just like you would if you were reading the pages yourself. 
I think that listening to an audiobook is bjusttas beneficialreading a book because iif you are just starting to learn to read, it's like you have a person reading along with you. Of course you should be reading the book yourself, along with listening to the audiobook at the same time. Pause and rewind as needed to give yourself time to read the pages. I personally know a person who taught themselves how to read using that method. It worked very well for them. 

I can not however say that an audiobook is better than good old fashion reading though because both do have minor differences about them like the fact that you can't see the words as you listen to the audiobook, or that you can't do other things while reading a book.
Pros and cons for both, but those do not make an audiobo

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, yes, listening to an audiobook is just as good as reading the paper pages of a book because it is the same story. You get the same information, and you can still enjoy the story. You still have to be involved with the story of course, just like you would if you were reading the pages yourself. 
I think that listening to an audiobook is bjusttas beneficialreading a book because iif you are just starting to learn to read, it's like you have a person reading along with you. Of course you should be reading the book yourself, along with listening to the audiobook at the same time. Pause and rewind as needed to give yourself time to read the pages. I personally know a person who taught themselves how to read using that method. It worked very well for them. 

I can not however say that an audiobook is better than good old fashion reading though because both do have minor differences about them like the fact that you can't see the words as you listen to the audiobook, or that you can't do other things while reading a book.
Pros and cons for both, but those do not make an audiobook better or worse tha

I can not however say that an audiobook is better than good old fashion reading though because both do have minor differences about them like the fact that you can't see the words as you listen to the audiobook, or that you can't do other things while reading a book.
Pros and cons for both, but those do not make an audiobook better or worse than reading and vice versa. Th

I personally know a person who taught themselves how to read using that method. It worked very well for them. 

I can not however say that an audiobook is better than good old fashion reading though because both do have minor differences about them like the fact that you can't see the words as you listen to the audiobook, or that you can't do other things while reading a book.
Pros and cons for both, but those do not make an audiobook better or worse than reading and vice versa. There really shouldn't be sides when it comes to any form o

Pros and cons for both, but those do not make an audiobook better or worse than reading and vice versa. There really shouldn't be sides when it comes to any form of reading. People that say a

In my opinion, yes, listening to an audiobook is just as good as reading the paper pages of a book because it is the same story. You get the same information, and you can still enjoy the story. You still have to be involved with the story of course, just like you would if you were reading the pages yourself. 
I think that listening to an audiobook is bjusttas beneficialreading a book because iif you are just starting to learn to read, it's like you have a person reading along with you. Of course you should be reading the book yourself, along with listening to the audiobook at the same time. Pause and rewind as needed to give yourself time to read the pages. I personally know a person who taught themselves how to read using that method. It worked very well for them. 

I can not however say that an audiobook is better than good old fashion reading though because both do have minor differences about them like the fact that you can't see the words as you listen to the audiobook, or that you can't do other things while reading a book.
Pros and cons for both, but those do not make an audiobook better or worse than reading and vice versa. There really shouldn't be sides when it comes to any form of reading. People that say audiobooks are trash because you don't read it yourself

I think that listening to an audiobook is bjusttas beneficialreading a book because iif you are just starting to learn to read, it's like you have a person reading along with you. Of course you should be reading the book yourself, along with listening to the audiobook at the same time. Pause and rewind as needed to give yourself time to read the pages. I personally know a person who taught themselves how to read using that method. It worked very well for them. 

I can not however say that an audiobook is better than good old fashion reading though because both do have minor differences about them like the fact that you can't see the words as you listen to the audiobook, or that you can't do other things while reading a book.
Pros and cons for both, but those do not make an audiobook better or worse than reading and vice versa. There really shouldn't be sides when it comes to any form of reading. People that say audiobooks are trash because you don't read it yourself must have forgotten whe

You still have to be involved with the story of course, just like you would if you were reading the pages yourself. 
I think that listening to an audiobook is bjusttas beneficialreading a book because iif you are just starting to learn to read, it's like you have a person reading along with you. Of course you should be reading the book yourself, along with listening to the audiobook at the same time. Pause and rewind as needed to give yourself time to read the pages. I personally know a person who taught themselves how to read using that method. It worked very well for them. 

I can not however say that an audiobook is better than good old fashion reading though because both do have minor differences about them like the fact that you can't see the words as you listen to the audiobook, or that you can't do other things while reading a book.
Pros and cons for both, but those do not make an audiobook better or worse than reading and vice versa. There really shouldn't be sides when it comes to any form of reading. People that say audiobooks are trash because you don't read it yourself must have forgotten when they were little kids and

People that say audiobooks are trash because you don't read it yourself must have forgotten when they were little kids and their parents read to the

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, yes, listening to an audiobook is just as good as reading the paper pages of a book because it is the same story. You get the same information, and you can still enjoy the story. You still have to be involved with the story of course, just like you would if you were reading the pages yourself. 
I think that listening to an audiobook is bjusttas beneficialreading a book because iif you are just starting to learn to read, it's like you have a person reading along with you. Of course you should be reading the book yourself, along with listening to the audiobook at the same time. Pause and rewind as needed to give yourself time to read the pages. I personally know a person who taught themselves how to read using that method. It worked very well for them. 

I can not however say that an audiobook is better than good old fashion reading though because both do have minor differences about them like the fact that you can't see the words as you listen to the audiobook, or that you can't do other things while reading a book.
Pros and cons for both, but those do not make an audiobook better or worse than reading and vice versa. There really shouldn't be sides when it comes to any form of reading. People that say audiobooks are trash because you don't read it yourself must have forgotten when they were little kids and their parents read to them

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, yes, listening to an audiobook is just as good as reading the paper pages of a book because it is the same story. You get the same information, and you can still enjoy the story. You still have to be involved with the story of course, just like you would if you were reading the pages yourself. 
I think that listening to an audiobook is bjusttas beneficialreading a book because iif you are just starting to learn to read, it's like you have a person reading along with you. Of course you should be reading the book yourself, along with listening to the audiobook at the same time. Pause and rewind as needed to give yourself time to read the pages. I personally know a person who taught themselves how to read using that method. It worked very well for them. 

I can not however say that an audiobook is better than good old fashion reading though because both do have minor differences about them like the fact that you can't see the words as you listen to the audiobook, or that you can't do other things while reading a book.
Pros and cons for both, but those do not make an audiobook better or worse than reading and vice versa. There really shouldn't be sides when it comes to any form of reading.
